S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Performance (mean ligand RMSD) of models on the validation and test sets of the interaction pose dataset (Dock2D-IP). The entire validation and test sets were used in evaluation (1017 and 11850 examples, respectively). The last two rows report how the features and energy function learned from the IF task perform on the IP task.
S4.T1.table:
Model # training examples Validation Test
Brute-force IP 1000 1.04 1.54
100 1.01 1.39
10 4.24 6.11
Simplified IP 1000 0.72 1.17
100 1.18 1.84
10 5.97 7.64
Brute-force IF a 5050 0.53 0.82
Sampled IF b 5050 1.27 2.05
references:
Table 1 shows the performance of the IP models on the Dock2D-IP validation and test sets. Although 4064 training examples are available in the Dock2D-IP dataset, the models were trained on fewer examples (1000, 100, and 10) to illustrate their data efficiency. All IP models were trained for 100 epochs (see Figure A.6 for the training curves).
Models reported in Table 1 have mean ligand RMSDs below 2 pixels, indicating that they recover the true poses within the resolution limits of the input.
The learned representations, shown in Figure 5, indicate that the models have also recovered the equivalent of the bulk and boundary features used by the generating function.

Interestingly, the performance of the model trained on the “simplified” IP task is comparable to that of the model trained on the full IP task (see Table 1).
We also note that very few training examples are needed to achieve optimal performance: Using 100 examples instead of 1000 does not significantly affect the performance. The performance is somewhat reduced when only 10 examples are used but that degradation is due to a small fraction of the validation/test examples for which an alternate pose is predicted (RSMD>10RSMD10\mathrm{RSMD}>10) (see Figure A.7).

The energy function learned from the IF task is directly transferable to the IP task and yields a comparable—if not better—performance (see the bottom two rows of Table 1).
By contrast, the energy function learned from the IP task, which has an undetermined scale because it only serves to identify the lowest-energy pose, can be transferred to the IF task only after appropriate re-scaling.
We perform that calibration by transferring to the IF model all parameters learned from the IP model but by re-training the “a𝑎a” coefficients (see Eq. (2)).
The corresponding “brute-force IFIP” models, which are pre-trained on the IP task and have only five learnable parameters (the “a𝑎a” coefficients and F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}; see Eq. (10)), perform on par with the brute-force IF model (see the second half of Table 2).

We have proposed the Dock2D datasets (Dock2D-IP and Dock2D-IF) and several representation-learning “baseline” models demonstrating end-to-end learning of a simplified, 2D version of the molecular recognition problem. The representation-learning baselines effectively solved the interaction pose (IP) prediction problem in two dimensions (see Table 1), whether they were trained on the full task of predicting optimal pose (𝐭0,ϕ0)subscript𝐭0subscriptitalic-ϕ0(\mathbf{t}_{0},\phi_{0}) or on the simplified task of predicting optimal translation 𝐭0subscript𝐭0\mathbf{t}_{0} given the ground-truth orientation ϕ0subscriptitalic-ϕ0\phi_{0}.
Training on the IP task (whether “brute-force” or “simplified”) was extremely efficient, requiring only 100 epochs and completing in minutes.

Training curves of the models presented in Table 1. For the brute-force models (in blue), cross-entropy loss ℒIPsubscriptℒIP\cal{L}_{\mathrm{IP}} is calculated for distribution (7); for the simplified models (in red), it is calculated for distribution (8). All models were trained for 100 epochs.

Distribution of ligand RMSD for the experiment from Table 1 yielding the poorest scores (training on the “simplified” IP task using only 10 examples). The average ligand RMSD is 0.37 for the training set (10 examples), 5.97 for the validation set (1017 examples), and 7.64 for the test set (11850 examples).

Model Subset Accuracy Precision Recall MCC

Test 0.99 0.99 0.93 0.95

Test 0.97 0.90 0.94 0.90

references:
Table 2 shows the performance of the IF models on the Dock2D-IF validation and test sets (see Figure A.8 for the training curves). Interpretation is complicated by the class imbalance of the dataset, which is about 15:1 for the training/validation set (15 non-interacting pairs for each interacting pair) and about 6:1 for the test set. To facilitate the comparison, we also report the performance using Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) [38].
All brute-force IF models have high accuracy and precision, whether they are trained in full (“brute-force IF”) or using SE(2)-CNN weights transferred from the IP model (“brute-force IFIP”). The lower recall values reflect the 1:15 and 1:6 imbalance between positive and negative examples.
Moreover, each model performs similarly on both the validation and test sets, despite the difference is class imbalance and the greater variety of shapes in the test set.

The energy function learned from the IF task is directly transferable to the IP task and yields a comparable—if not better—performance (see the bottom two rows of Table 1).
By contrast, the energy function learned from the IP task, which has an undetermined scale because it only serves to identify the lowest-energy pose, can be transferred to the IF task only after appropriate re-scaling.
We perform that calibration by transferring to the IF model all parameters learned from the IP model but by re-training the “a𝑎a” coefficients (see Eq. (2)).
The corresponding “brute-force IFIP” models, which are pre-trained on the IP task and have only five learnable parameters (the “a𝑎a” coefficients and F0subscript𝐹0F_{0}; see Eq. (10)), perform on par with the brute-force IF model (see the second half of Table 2).

The baselines also solved the fact-of-interaction (IF) prediction problem (see Table 2), whether the predicted Δ​FΔ𝐹\Delta F values used in the ℒIFsubscriptℒIF\cal{L}_{\mathrm{IF}} loss were computed explicitly using Eq. (11) or sampled using Eq. (13).
While training models on the IF task took significantly longer—requiring 1000 epochs and sometimes taking days to complete—, training time can be drastically reduced by starting from the energy function learned from the IP task (see Figure A.8).
Training curves of the models presented in Table 2. The brute-force models pre-trained by transferring the energy function learned from the IP task (red curves) did not require as extensive training.
